Available online 10 February 2025 Article Surface confinement of sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters on 1D/2D NiO nanotubes/nanosheets as an effective electrocatalyst for urea-assisted energy-saving hydrogen production Jiaxin Li a Yan Lv a Xueyan Wu a Xinyu Guo a Zhuojun Yang a Jixi Guo a * Tianhua Zhou a b * Dianzeng Jia a * a State Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Utilization of Carbon Based Energy Resources; College of Chemistry, Xinjiang University, Urumqi 830017, Xinjiang, China State Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Utilization of Carbon Based Energy Resources; College of Chemistry Xinjiang University Urumqi Xinjiang 830017 China State Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Utilization of Carbon Based Energy Resources; College of Chemistry, Xinjiang University, Urumqi 830017, Xinjiang, China b State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou 350002, Fujian, China State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter Chinese Academy of Sciences Fuzhou Fujian 350002 China State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou 350002, Fujian, China * Corresponding author To address the high cost and limited electrochemical endurance of Pt-based electrocatalysts, the appropriate introduction of transition metal-based compounds as supports to disperse and anchor Pt species offers a promising approach for improving catalytic efficiency. In this study, sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters were uniformly confined on NiO supports with a hierarchical nanotube/nanosheet structure (Pt/NiO/NF) through a combination of spatial domain confinement and annealing. The resulting catalyst exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity and stability for hydrogen evolution (HER) and urea oxidation reactions (UOR) under alkaline conditions. Structural characterization and density functional theory calculations demonstrated that sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters were immobilized on the NiO supports by Pt–O–Ni bonds at the interface. The strong metal-support interaction induced massive charge redistribution around the heterointerface, leading to the formation of multiple active sites. The Pt/NiO/NF catalyst only required an overpotential of 12 and 136 mV to actuate current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 for the HER, respectively, and maintained a voltage retention of 96% for 260 h of continuous operation at a current density of 500 mA cm−2. Notably, in energy-efficient hydrogen production systems coupled with the HER and UOR, the catalyst required cell voltages of 1.37 and 1.53 V to drive current densities of 10 and 50 mA cm−2, respectively—approximately 300 mV lower than conventional water electrolysis systems. This study presents a novel pathway for designing highly efficient and robust sub-nanometer metal cluster catalysts. Keywords Metal-support interaction Sub-nanometric cluster Hydrogen evolution reaction Size engineering Urea oxidation reaction 1 Introduction Dispersing catalytically active metal nanoparticles (NPs) on supports is widely employed in heterogeneous catalyst design, enhancing noble metal utilization and decreasing catalyst costs [ 1–6 ]. Numerous studies have demonstrated that when NP size is reduced to the sub-nanometer scale (<50 atoms), the ratio of the number of corresponding surface atoms to the total number of atoms increases significantly, which is important for the cost-effective development of metal-based catalyst [ 4,7 ]. Reducing cluster size to 1 nm or less compared to larger NPs further enhances this effect. Sub-nanoclusters (SNCs) possess lower metal-metal coordination numbers than larger NPs, enabling more metal atoms in SNCs to be accessible for reactant and intermediate adsorption and activation [ 1,8,9 ]. Additionally, SNCs catalysts with abundant metal-metal and metal-support bonds can modulate metal-support interactions by adjusting metal-metal bond ratios, forming more active sites for the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules. This adaptability broadens the utility of SNCs catalysts across different reactions [ 10–13 ]. Despite their advantages, SNCs catalysts face challenges due to their high surface energy and robust covalent bonding, making them structurally unstable and prone to agglomeration under harsh operating conditions. This instability presents a significant obstacle in fabricating and sustaining their nanostructures [ 3,14–16 ]. However, strong metal-support interactions (SMSIs) can alleviate agglomeration and detachment of the nanocluster portion, preserving the high catalytic performance of SNCs catalysts during extended operation. This approach offers a promising solution for developing efficient and stable SNCs catalysts [ 2,17,18 ]. Recently, metal oxides have emerged as promising supports due to their ability to form strong electronic metal-support interactions (EMSIs) through metal-oxygen bonds anchoring metal clusters to the supports [ 19,20 ]. Reducible metal oxides such as TiO2, CeO2, and NiO, in particular, feature ligand-unsaturated cation sites that facilitate interfacial charge transfer and electronic rearrangement. This occurs due to differences in Fermi energy levels between the metal clusters and support, thereby promoting EMSIs [ 21–23 ]. NiO is highly resistant to severe reaction conditions, showing minimal degradation or corrosion compared to carbon-based materials. This robustness makes NiO highly suitable for various multiphase catalytic applications [ 24–26 ]. In addition, NiO materials possess SMSI and exhibit strong synergistic effects [ 27,28 ]. The enhanced SMSI not only stabilizes the active constituents of the SNCs but also optimizes the electronic configuration of the active sites in the SNCs, thus facilitating the rapid occurrence of the electrocatalytic reaction [ 29,30 ]. However, the construction of complexes loaded with metal SNCs on oxide supports through facile synthetic methods is still lacking, despite the tremendous efforts made in recent years for the development of NP/oxide composites. In addition, the mechanism of synergistic interaction between metal SNCs and oxide supports in electrocatalytic reactions requires further research [ 31,32 ]. In this study, we employed spatial confinement and annealing methods to fabricate Pt sub-nanocluster catalysts loaded on a nanotube/nanosheet hierarchical structured NiO support (Pt/NiO/NF). These catalysts demonstrated exceptional electrocatalytic performance for both HER and UOR. The Pt species were auto-reduced and immobilized on the NiO nanotubes/nanosheets, and the 1D/2D hierarchical structure minimized self-accumulation/agglomeration of the sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters while maximizing their exposure. When the as-prepared Pt/NiO/NF catalyst was utilized as a self-supporting electrode to generate hydrogen in the HER || UOR coupled system, it required a cell voltage of only 1.53 V to achieve a current density of 50 mA cm–2––approximately 300 mV lower than that of the conventional water electrolysis system under identical conditions. Microstructural analysis and theoretical calculations demonstrate that the sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters are immobilized on the NiO supports through Pt-O-Ni bonds, facilitating electron transfer from Pt to the NiO supports. This EMSI contributed to the hydrogen spillover effect of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst, providing a pathway for the transfer of hydrogen intermediates to facilitate the reaction kinetics. In addition, the amount of Pt species loaded on the NiO support was approximately 3.1 wt%, resulting in outstanding catalytic performance and low cost, establishing the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst as a highly promising Pt-based catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials NiCl2·6H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, CO(NH2)2, KOH, NaCl, absolute ethanol, nickel foam (NF) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The theoretically expected amount of H2 was then calculated by applying the Faraday law, which states that the passage of 96500 C causes 1 equivalent of reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of Pt/NiO/NF To synthesize a catalyst with sub-nanoscale Pt nanoclusters loaded on NiO nanotubes/nanosheets, a 1D/2D Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF precursor nanowire/nanosheet array was initially grown on three-dimensional (3D) porous Ni foam (NF) using a classical hydrothermal method. As shown in Scheme 1 , hierarchically structured Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF nanowires/nanosheets were synthesized using a space-confined method. Ultrafine one-dimensional (1D) Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF nanowires were grown in situ within a 3D space formed by two-dimensional (2D) Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF nanosheets. This space-confined reaction involved PtCl6 2– and Ni2+ in the presence of urea and NaCl, resulting in the formation of 1D/2D Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF nanowire/nanosheet hierarchical structure. The crystal structure was characterized by XRD, confirming the successful synthesis of Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF on the nickel foam substrate (Fig. S1). Comparative experiments (Figs. S2–S4) revealed that nanosheets or nanowires were observed at higher temperatures or in the case of Cl− and urea, respectively, and the presence of a hierarchical structure of 1D/2D nanowires/nanosheets was not observed. These results indicate that chloride ions (Cl−) play an important role as structural guides in controlling the formation of hierarchical 1D/2D nanowires/nanosheets during the synthesis of the precursor Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF, with the process requiring lower temperatures and moderate urea concentrations. As shown in the second step of Scheme 1, a Pt/NiO/NF metal/semiconductor compound was fabricated via calcination of the precursors during annealing. The metal/metal oxide conversion mechanism involved the coordinated treatment of low-valence (2+ valence) Ni ions and high-valence (3.4+ valence) Pt ions in the Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF precursor, which formed Pt/NiO/NF composites with nanocluster/nanotube/nanosheet hierarchical structure. This formation was facilitated by the kirkendall effect [ 33 ]. Significantly, the resulting Pt/NiO/NF composites exhibited abundant metal/metal oxide interfaces, facilitating rapid charge transfer and efficient ion diffusion to the catalytically active sites. This structural feature enabled the designed Pt/NiO/NF catalyst to possess bifunctional HER and UOR catalytic activities. 3.2 Characterization of Pt/NiO/NF The structure, morphology, and composition of Pt/NiO/NF were characterized and compared with those of NiO/NF. XRD patterns verified that NiO has a cubic crystal structure (JCPDS No. 71-1179) with characteristic peaks at 37.3°, 43.3°, 62.9°, and 75.4°, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) crystal planes of NiO (Fig. 1(a) ). In addition, characteristic peaks at 39.5°, 46.0°, 67.1°, and 80.8° were attributed to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) crystal planes of Pt (Fig. 1(a)), verifying the successful loading of Pt species with a cubic crystal phase on the NiO supports (JCPDS No. 87-0636). The XRD results showed that the precursor Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF completely transformed into Pt/NiO/NF metal/oxide composites during annealing. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) determined the Pt content of Pt/NiO/NF to be ≈ 3.1 wt%, indicating the successful immobilization of Pt species on the NiO/NF. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) are used to analyze the morphology of the Pt/NiO/NF. For comparison, NiO/NF was synthesized under identical conditions (Fig. S6). Compared to the morphology of the precursor Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF (Fig. S2), the Pt/NiO/NF metal/oxide composite showed a vertical nanosheet structure with nanoclusters and nanotubes forming in situ on the nanosheets, creating a nanocluster/nanotube/nanosheet hierarchical structure (Figs. 1(b), (c)). The uniform distribution of Pt nanoclusters can be ascribed to their in situ transformation and the strong interactions between Pt and NiO supports, which inhibit the thermal relocation of Pt atoms into large NPs during annealing. The low-resolution TEM (LR-TEM) image (Fig. S7(a)) further shows the formation of Pt/NiO/NF metal/oxide nanocluster/nanotube/nanosheet hierarchical nanostructure. High-resolution (HR)-TEM images (Fig. 1(e) and Figs. S7(b), (c)) show the presence of nanotubes, with Pt nanoclusters uniformly distributed on the nanotubes, collectively forming a nanocluster/nanotube hierarchical structure. Statistical analysis of particle size (Fig. 1(d)) revealed that the size of the Pt sub-nanoclusters anchored on the NiO/NF supports had an average size of approximately 1.1 nm (equivalent to 3–4 atomic layers). The minimal particle size and porous structure of the catalyst provide a substantial number of exposed edge regions, which serve as active sites. Furthermore, these uniformly distributed nanocluster/nanotube hierarchical nanoarrays interconnect to create a 3D porous structure, increasing the number of electrochemically active sites and facilitating the release of gas bubbles. The contact angle measurements verified the hydrophilic properties of the materials (Fig. S9), indicating excellent immersion wettability that accelerates the electrocatalytic reaction. The hierarchical structure of NiO nanotubes/nanosheets offers a large surface area for the uniform confinement of sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters and facilitates rapid charge transport, thereby enhancing surface micromanipulation mechanical properties. Further structural investigation of the as-prepared catalysts through HR-TEM analysis (Figs. 1(f), (g)) revealed interplanar distances of approximately 0.241 and 0.227 nm, corresponding to the (111) and (111) crystal planes of NiO and Pt, respectively. During the formation of metals and oxides, strains and defects generated oxygen vacancies and edge-active sites. These edge sites largely exposed the (111) and (111) crystal planes of Pt and NiO, contributing to the catalytic activity (Fig. 1(f)). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern reveals the crystallinity of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst (Fig. 1(h)), demonstrating the coexistence of the metallic Pt and semiconducting NiO phases. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) patterns and elemental mapping images (Fig. S8 and Fig. 1(i)) further confirmed the uniform distribution of Pt, Ni, and O within the Pt/NiO/NF hierarchical nanostructures. These results align with the XRD data, collectively indicating that sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters confined on the surface of NiO supports with a hierarchical structure enable Pt nanocluster catalysts to be directly exposed to electrolytes and bound to reactants/intermediates, thereby significantly improving the catalytic performance of Pt/NiO/NF catalysts. To assess the specific surface area and hierarchical porosity of the Pt/NiO/NF structures, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distribution curves were analyzed for the Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF precursor, Pt/NiO/NF, and NiO/NF (Fig. S10). The representative type-IV isotherm with a distinct hysteresis loop confirmed the presence of a hierarchical pore structure, further verified by pore size distribution curves. Specific surface areas measured using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method for Ni1.14Pt2.86O6/NF precursor, Pt/NiO/NF, and NiO/NF were 24.12, 25.51, and 24.66 m2 g−1, respectively. These results indicate that the nanotube/nanosheet hierarchical pore structure of the NiO supports effectively confines and anchors sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters, enabling their in-situ growth. Notably, SMSI between the hierarchically structured NiO supports and sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters facilitates abundant electron transfer pathways at the heterointerfaces and minimizes the electrical resistance of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts, thereby reducing the overpotentials for the catalytic process–an essential factor for enhancing both HER and UOR activities. Surface charge distribution is a crucial parameter in the catalytic reaction process and has received significant attention. The surface chemistry, electronic properties, and work function of the obtained Pt/NiO/NF catalysts were analyzed using XPS and ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS). As shown in Figs. 2(a) , the calculated power function value of Pt is 4 eV, significantly lower than that of NiO (6 eV), which satisfies the energy band conditions necessary to form a Schottky barrier. In the practical application of Pt/NiO/NF catalysts (Fig. 2(b)), the Schottky barrier induces the redistribution of electrons and band bending at the heterogeneous interface, prompting electron transfer from the Pt metallic phase to the NiO semiconductor phase until the equilibrium of the work function is achieved. This electron rearrangement at the Pt-NiO heterointerface creates a continuous electron transport channel, increasing the density of the electrocatalytic active sites and accelerating the rate of the electrocatalytic reaction by reducing the energy barrier for the formation of reaction intermediates. This improved the electrocatalytic kinetics of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst [ 34 ]. The XPS survey spectrum indicated the occurrence of signal peaks of Pt, Ni, and O in the Pt/NiO/NF composites compared to NiO/NF, whereas only the signal peaks of Ni and O were observed in NiO/NF (Fig. S11), consistent with XRD and EDX results. All XPS spectra were calibrated using the C 1s peak, which had a binding energy of 284.8 eV. As shown in the Pt 4f spectrum (Fig. 2(c)), both Pt 4f 7/2 and Pt 4f 5/2 peaks were deconvoluted into two distinct components. Peaks at 76.08 and 71.49 eV correspond to the 4f 5/2 and 4f 7/2 states of Pt0, with binding energies shifted upward relative to reported values for Pt0 in NPs (74.7 and 71.3 eV) [ 36 ]. This indicates that the introduction of the NiO support caused changes in the electronic structures of the Pt clusters. Additionally, the two peaks at 77.66 and 73.25 eV are attributed to the characteristic 4f 5/2 and 4f 7/2 peaks of Pt δ+ species bonded to O atoms. The high-resolution spectrum of Ni 2p for Pt/NiO/NF (Fig. 2(d)) shows peaks at 855.62 and 873.00 eV, attributed to 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 of Ni2+, respectively, along with satellite peaks at 860.88 and 879.23 eV. Compared to NiO/NF, the binding energy of the Ni 2p spectrum for Pt/NiO/NF shifts to lower binding energy, indicating that the anchoring of Pt clusters triggers changes in the electronic structure of the NiO support surface, resulting from electron redistribution between the Pt sub-nanoclusters and the surface atoms of the NiO support. As illustrated in Fig. 2(e), the O 1s spectrum of Pt/NiO/NF reveals three peaks at 529.18, 531.13, and 532.44 eV, which are attributed to metal-oxygen bonding in metal oxides, O–H bonds in water molecules adsorbed on the surface of the material, and adsorbed oxygen, respectively [ 35 ]. Compared to that of NiO/NF, the O 1s peak of Pt/NiO/NF shifted towards a lower binding energy. Combined with the downward shift of the characteristic O 1s peak, the formation of a Pt–O bond in the Pt/NiO/NF complex was confirmed. These observations suggest the presence of strong electron metal-support interactions in the Pt/NiO/NF heterogeneous catalyst, enabling electron transfer from the Pt metal phase to the NiO semiconductor phase. This observation is corroborated by subsequent density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The valence band spectrum of Pt/NiO/NF is considerably broadened compared to that of NiO/NF, with a positive shift in the valence band maximum (VBM) (Fig. 2(f)), indicating a shift in the d-band center away from the Fermi energy level. The weak adsorption of Oads at the Pt sites typically hampers water dissociation kinetics in Pt-based catalysts despite the optimal adsorption energy of the Pt sites on Hads [ 37 ]. However, the anchoring of sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters on NiO supports via Pt–O bonds in Pt/NiO/NF catalysts facilitates the formation of strong EMSI between metal-oxygen bonds and metal oxides, and interfacial modulation and the construction of an internal electric field, thereby significantly enhancing catalytic activity. 3.3 Catalytic activity toward HER The catalytic activity of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst towards the HER in a 1.0 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte with saturated Ar was investigated. The activity of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst was enhanced by optimizing the loading of Pt NPs and regulating oxidation temperature to precisely control the dimensions of the Pt NPs. Figs. S13 and S16 show that the size of sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters increased to 2.26 nm in the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts when Pt loading was increased from 2.0 to 2.4 mmol. This increase led to significant agglomeration of Pt clusters, hindering the exposure of the active sites and inhibiting rapid charge transport, which negatively impacted catalytic performance. At the oxidation temperature of 350 °C, subnanoclusters in the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts migrated to larger sizes (Fig. S17), forming 3.48 nm Pt NPs accompanied by extensive agglomeration. The increase in the Pt nanoparticle size reduced the atomic utilization efficiency of the active Pt sites in the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst, significantly diminishing its intrinsic catalytic activity (Fig. S15). As shown in Figs. 3(a) and S14, the polarization curves indicated that the overpotential of Pt/NiO/NF was only 11.8 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. This overpotential was significantly lower than those of NiO/NF (232.8 mV) and commercial Pt/C (32.6 mV). Notably, the HER activity of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst was significantly higher than that of a commercial Pt/C electrode. For higher current densities, commercial Pt/C requires an overpotential of 207.7 mV to achieve a current density of 100 mA cm−2, whereas Pt/NiO/NF only requires an overpotential of 135.6 mV. These results indicate that the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst has a wide potential range and excellent HER catalytic activity (Fig. 3(b)). As shown in Table S4, the performance of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts is excellent compared to that of some representative loaded Pt-based catalysts that have been reported to date. In addition, the addition of urea to the electrolyte had a negligible effect on the HER activity of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst (Fig. S12), suggesting its effectiveness in the coupled HER||UOR system for enhanced H2 production. Fig. 3(c) illustrates the Tafel slopes of the catalysts used to analyze electrocatalytic kinetics for the HER. The Pt/NiO/NF catalyst exhibited a Tafel slope of 46 mV dec−1, slightly lower than commercial Pt/C (49 mV dec−1), and much lower than the NiO/NF catalyst (191 mV dec−1), demonstrating favorable HER kinetics consistent with the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism in an alkaline electrolyte. This superior kinetic performance of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst was further demonstrated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis. As displayed in Fig. 3(d), the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst possesses the lowest charge transfer resistance (0.43 Ω), which is much lower than that of NiO/NF (16.86 Ω) and the commercial Pt/C catalyst (2.99 Ω). These findings suggest that loading sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters onto NiO supports with nanotube/nanosheet hierarchical structures enhances conductivity and electron transfer characteristics, significantly contributing to the HER activity of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts. The intrinsic catalytic activity of the catalyst was further determined using cyclic voltammetry to measure the double layer capacitance (C dl), where the C dl value is proportional to the ECSA of the sample. The C dl value of 4.42 mF cm−2 for Pt/NiO/NF was much higher than that of NiO/NF (0.79 mF cm−2) and NF (0.59 mF cm−2), as illustrated in Fig. 3(e). The calculated ECSA of Pt/NiO/NF (2.62 cm2) was also substantially larger than that of NiO/NF (0.47 cm2) and NF (0.35 cm2) (Fig. S19 and Table S1). To evaluate the intrinsic catalytic activity of the catalyst, the number of surface-active sites (N) and turnover frequency (TOF) were calculated at an overpotential of 200 mV. The calculated N and TOF of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst were 7.8 × 10−8 mol and 6.8 s−1 far exceeding those of the NiO/NF and commercial Pt/C (Figs. 3(f) and S20). After normalizing the current density of the polarization curves to the TOF and ECSA, the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst exhibited excellent performance, indicating its high intrinsic catalytic activity (Figs. S21 and S22). The remarkable enhancement in the activity of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts is attributed to the higher atom utilization provided by sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters and the optimized surface electronic properties of the Pt and NiO supports. In addition to catalytic activity, catalyst stability is a critical consideration in the development of electrocatalysts. As shown in the inset of Fig. 3(g), the potential-time curve shows that the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst has negligible potential decay after 60 h of operation, with a potential retention rate of 92%. This finding underscores the excellent catalytic stability for the HER. Moreover, the catalytic activity of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts remained stable, as demonstrated by the nearly identical LSV curves before and after the 5000-cycle CV tests (Fig. 3(g)). Notably, the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst achieved an excellent voltage retention of 96% during continuous operation at an industrial-grade current density of 500 mA cm−2 over 260 h, as shown by chronopotential analysis (Fig. 3(h)). These results highlight the excellent activity and stability of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst. To understand the robustness of Pt/NiO/NF electrodes under such high current densities for extended durations, post-stability tests were conducted using SEM, TEM, ICP-OES, and XPS analyses. SEM (Fig. S23) and TEM (Fig. S24) results indicated that the morphology of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts remained almost unchanged after the prolonged HER stability tests. EDX and ICP-OES analyses demonstrated that the Pt content in the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst remained stable at ~3% after the HER stability test (Fig. S25 and Table S3). This stability is attributed to the effective anchoring of sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters to the NiO support via Pt–O bonding, which prevents agglomeration and detachment of Pt sub-nanoclusters during the HER cycling. XPS analysis further elucidated the surface chemical state of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst after the HER stability tests (Fig. S26). After the HER test, the Ni 2p spectrum of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst showed negligible changes (Fig. S26(b)), confirming the excellent stability of the catalyst. Notably, the Pt 4f 5/2 and 4f 7/2 peaks shifted toward lower binding energies compared to those of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts prior to the stability test (Fig. S26(c)). Furthermore, the decrease in the percentage of Pt δ+ suggests that some Pt δ+ was reduced to Pt0 during the HER. Additionally, the valence-band spectrum (Fig. S26(e)) revealed a negative shift in the VBM, suggesting enhanced electronic modulation of the Pt active sites by the NiO support. This modulation promotes stronger adsorption of Hads on the Pt sites. NiO promotes water dissociation by enhancing the adsorption of OH–, while the integration of Pt and NiO enhances the HER performance through a bifunctional mechanism. Specifically, NiO facilitates HO–H bond cleavage, and Pt promotes the adsorption of H+ and subsequent recombination into H2, thereby enhancing the aqueous dissociation kinetics and enhancing the water dissociation performance of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst [ 38 ]. The electrochemical performance of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts is superior to that of other reported electrocatalysts (Table S4). 3.4 Catalytic mechanism of HER revealed by DFT calculations DFT calculations were performed to gain insight into the intrinsic mechanism underlying the remarkable HER electrocatalytic performance of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4(a) and Figs. S27(a), (b), a composite model of Pt clusters supported on NiO (denoted as Pt/NiO/NF) and a structural model of NiO (denoted as NiO/NF) were constructed based on experimental results. Fig. 4(b) reveals significant charge redistribution and exchange at the heterogeneous interface between the Pt clusters and NiO. Pt acts as an electron source, generating charge transfer from Pt to NiO and reducing Ni2+/3+ in the NiO. Bader charge analysis indicates the transfer of ≈ 2.74 |e| from the surface of Pt clusters to NiO, generating a strong electric field that significantly enhances electron transfer during the catalytic process [ 39 ]. The electron cloud is enriched at the top of the Pt cluster, promoting strong H* trapping at these sites, while the electron depletion at the Pt-NiO interface inhibits the large accumulation of interfacial charge and promotes hydrogen spillover kinetics. This deficiency in interfacial electron density of Pt/NiO diminishes H* adsorption at the interfacial Pt sites, enhancing HER activity of Pt through effective interfacial hydrogen spillover. These findings emphasize the effective construction of a built-in electric field between the metal and support in designing high-efficiency metal-support electrocatalysts. To further understand the electronic structures of the Pt/NiO catalysts, projected density of state (PDOS) analysis was performed (Fig. S28). The Pt-5d orbital exhibits a peak close to E F, at –0.18 eV, corresponding to active HER sites and enabling rapid electron transfer with low energy barriers. The Ni-3d orbitals possess a wide range, stabilizing the valence state of Pt and facilitating the effective adsorption of the intermediates. The high-valence Ni site contributes to the proximity of the Pt-5d orbital to E F, enhancing the electrochemical activity of the Pt sites. The O-2p orbital, positioned further from the E F, demonstrates electron-rich characteristics that balance surface electroactivity and inhibit over-binding effects of Pt–H and Ni–O. The PDOSs of the Ni-3d orbitals in Pt/NiO/NF were further analyzed, as shown in Fig. 4(d). Compared to NiO, the d-band center of Pt/NiO deviates toward E F, elevating the d-band center of the Ni sites near adjacent Pt sites and ensuring efficient electron transfer during the HER process. The O-2p orbitals in Pt/NiO are distant from those of E F and have a narrower band gap than NiO, while their electronic structure is influenced by the coordination number of the O site (Fig. 4(e)), resulting in a less energetic antibonding state that is more easily occupied. Additionally, the moderate d-band center of Pt/NiO compared to Pt (Fig. 4(f)) optimizes the water dissociation process to form additional H-intermediates and balance its adsorption/desorption, improving the value of ΔG H* and facilitating H2 formation. These results demonstrate that the Pt/NiO heterostructure promotes electrical conductivity, enhances the adsorption of hydrogen intermediates on the Pt clusters, and exploits the catalytic activity of neighboring NiO surfaces. The essential reaction steps of the alkaline HER on Pt/NiO heterosurfaces were investigated using DFT calculations, incorporating Pt (111) and NiO (111) surfaces. The H2O adsorption/dissociation and hydrogen adsorption energy barriers were determined using DFT calculations. Fig. S29 shows the calculated adsorption energies of H2O at the Ni site (0.55 eV), top Pt sites (1.67 eV), and interfacial Pt sites (1.28 eV). As reported in the literature, with an estimated energy barrier of 0.70 eV to break the H–OH bond on the Pt (111) surface, the energy required to dissociate H2O into Hads is very high [ 40 ]. _ENREF_47Comparatively, the Pt/NiO heterojunction showed the lowest water dissociation energy (0.31 eV), favoring the formation of H2O cleavage into Hads (Fig. 4(h)). It is speculated that the adsorption of H2O occurs at the top Pt site, where the introduction of the built-in electric field and the construction of the Pt-NiO interface together optimize the electronic structure of the Pt cluster, thus enhancing the adsorption and dissociation of H2O on Pt/NiO (Figs. S30 and S31). Subsequently, Hads generated by H2O dissociation can proceed through the Heyrovsky or Tafel steps to produce H2. Between these two steps, G Hads serves as the active descriptor of the catalyst. The calculated values of ΔG Hads for NiO (111) and Pt/NiO (111) surfaces are shown in Fig. 4(g). The ΔG H on the NiO surface is significantly more positive than the optimal value (ΔG Hads = 0), indicating that H2 is difficult to detach from the NiO surface. In contrast, the negative values of ΔG Hads are much smaller and closer to the optimal values reported in the literature for Hads on Pt (111) [ 36 ]. Therefore, Hads is more likely to form H2 on the Pt (111) surface than on the NiO surface. In addition, the free energies of Hads on Pt/NiO with different-sized Pt clusters were calculated. As shown in Fig. S32(e), the free energy required for the binding of Hads on the Pt sites to generate H2 significantly increases with the size of the Pt cluster, indicating that the catalytic activity of larger Pt clusters for the generation of H2 on Pt/NiO gradually decreases. This can be attributed to changes in the electronic structure of the larger Pt cluster, which lead to stronger Hads adsorption, thus increasing the energy barrier for H2 desorption and reducing the availability of active sites. Therefore, the HER performance of a Pt/NiO catalyst can be effectively enhanced by modulating the size of the Pt cluster to optimize its electronic structure. Overall, these calculations indicate a strong electronic interaction between the Pt clusters and NiO supports. The electronic structure of the Pt/NiO heterojunction can be effectively modulated by introducing a built-in electric field to optimize the adsorption/desorption strengths of the active intermediates, which is consistent with the electrocatalytic performance observed in our experiments. 3.5 Catalytic activity toward UOR Replacing the OER, with a thermodynamic potential of 1.23 V, by the UOR, which exhibits a thermodynamic potential of only 0.37 V, can generate energy savings of 70%. This approach provides a promising strategy to improve the energy efficiency of electrochemical devices. The findings demonstrate that the catalysts with sub-nanometer-scale Pt clusters loaded on NiO supports (Pt/NiO/NF) possess not only excellent HER catalytic activity but also superior UOR catalytic performance. The electrocatalytic UOR activity of Pt/NiO/NF was evaluated in a 1.0 mol L−1 KOH solution containing 0.5 mol L−1 urea using a classic three-electrode system. The loading of the sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters was optimized to obtain Pt/NiO/NF (Fig. S33). The LSV curves of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst for the UOR and water oxidation reactions (Fig. 5(a) ), show that the anodic current of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst significantly increased after the addition of 0.5 mol L−1 urea to the solution, indicating that the UOR occurs preferentially over OER. This substitution facilitates efficient hydrogen production at lower potentials. Furthermore, the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst significantly enhanced the catalytic activity for the OER and UOR by driving a higher current density at identical potentials and lower onset potentials than NiO/NF (Fig. 5(c)). As shown in Fig. 5(b), the UOR of the Pt/NiO/NF composites exhibits a significantly lower potential than that of the OER at the same current density. Electrocatalytic performance tests were performed in electrolytes containing different urea concentrations, and the optimal UOR activity of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst was achieved when the urea concentration was 0.5 mol L−1 (Fig. S34). Notably, at a current density of 100 mA cm−2, the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst requires only 1.43 V for UOR, compared to 1.68 V for OER. These results confirm that using UOR instead of the OER as the anode reaction, combined with this catalyst design, enables energy-efficient hydrogen production. Remarkably, the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst achieves current densities of 50 and 100 mA cm−2 at potentials of 1.38 and 1.43 V, respectively (Table S5), outperforming most reported UOR catalysts. The Tafel slopes of catalysts for UOR (Fig. 5(d)) show that the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst has a Tafel slope of 42.2 mV dec−1, significantly lower than those of NiO/NF and commercial RuO2 (55.1 and 72.4 mV dec−1), indicating enhanced kinetics due to the Pt/NiO/NF heterostructure. The UOR kinetics of the catalyst were investigated using EIS (Fig. 5(e)). The Pt/NiO/NF catalyst has the smallest charge transfer resistance (R ct) (0.43 Ω), which corresponds to the smallest Tafel slope value of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst (Fig. 5(e)). Compared to NiO/NF and RuO2/NF, the kinetic performance of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst is superior, and the results suggest that the activated Ni species after loading the Pt nanoclusters act as electrocatalytic active sites for UOR. The intrinsic electrocatalytic activities of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts were further investigated by estimating their ECSA from their double-layer capacitances (C dl). The Pt/NiO/NF catalysts exhibited the largest C dl and roughness factor (RF) values (60.25 mF cm−2 and 15.61) compared to NiO/NF (58.70 mF cm− 2 and 11.36) and NF (35.70 mF cm−2 and 1.00) (Fig. 5(f), Figs. S35 and S36), indicating that Pt/NiO/NF (5.46 cm2) possesses a relatively larger electrochemically active area than NiO/NF (3.98 cm2) and NF (0.35 cm2) (Table S2). These results indicate that the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst has superior electrocatalytic activity, larger ECSA, and abundant active sites, which greatly contribute to the improvement of UOR activity. The Pt/NiO/NF catalysts not only enhanced the active sites of the catalysts but also accelerated the rapid charge transfer in the electrocatalytic reaction, indicating that the strong EMSI between the sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters and NiO supports significantly boosts the UOR kinetics. Fig. 5(g) shows the multi-chronopotentiometry curves of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH and 0.5 mol L−1 urea, along with the comparison plot of the LSV curve after 5000 cycles. The catalyst retained ~99% of its potential after 60 h of continuous operation, with minimal changes in the LSV curves after cyclic stability testing. These results confirm the exceptional stability and durability of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst for the UOR in an alkaline environment, indicating its capacity to maintain high catalytic activity over extended operation periods. After long-term UOR stability testing, the morphology, chemical structure, and composition of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst were further characterized using SEM, TEM, ICP-OES, and XPS. SEM analysis (Fig. S37) revealed that the nanosheet morphology of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts was well maintained after the UOR stability test. The observed growth of small nanosheets on the surface of the nanosheets is likely attributable to the formation of Ni(OH)2 species after the UOR test. TEM images (Fig. S38) further confirmed the stability of the nanosheets and the generation of Ni(OH)2 small nanosheets. EDX and ICP-OES analyses (Fig. S39 and Table S3) demonstrated that the size and content of the Pt sub-nanoclusters in the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst remained stable after the UOR stability test. This indicates that the effective anchoring of Pt sub-nanoclusters to NiO supports with Pt–O bonds prevents agglomeration and detachment. In addition, XPS characterization (Fig. S40) provided insights into the surface chemical state of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst following the UOR stability testing. While the peak positions of all the elements were maintained (Fig. S40(a)), their intensities declined, likely due to the modification in the elemental composition induced by long-term stability tests. Notably, new peaks corresponding to Ni3+ species were observed in the Ni 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 regions (Fig. S40(b)), indicating the presence of catalytically active NiO(OH). A slight increase in Pt valency (Fig. S40(c)) was also noted, possibly due to the high oxidation potential of Pt during the UOR. Electrocatalytic urea oxidation starts with the formation of NiO(OH), indicating that Ni δ+ is active in the UOR. During the UOR, catalytically active NiO(OH) (containing Ni3+) is electrochemically reduced by urea to non-reactive Ni(OH)2 (containing Ni2+), while urea is chemically oxidized to its end product [ 38 ]. The formation of M–O and M–OH bonds in the high magnification XPS spectrum (Fig. S40(d)) of O 1s further confirmed the formation of NiO(OH) and Ni(OH)2. In addition, Figs. S37 and S38 demonstrate that the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst exhibited Ni(OH)2 nanosheet generation on the material surface after extended UOR stability testing, which corresponds to the above results. Furthermore, the VBM of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst exhibited a positive shift after stability testing (Fig. S40(e)), indicating that the d-band center of the catalyst shifted away from the Fermi level. This shift suggests that UOR activity occurs on the surface of the Ni(OH)2 derived from Ni within the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts. The modulation of electron density at the Ni(OH)2/NiO heterogeneous interface by Pt nanoclusters enhances UOR catalytic performance, as Ni sites strongly adsorb OHads [ 41 ]. To gain deeper insights into the reaction mechanism of the as-prepared catalysts during the UOR, we used in situ FTIR spectroscopy to monitor bond rupture and formation. As shown in Figs. 6(a) and S41(a), distinct vibrational peaks at ν = 2168 cm−1 were observed for both the Pt/NiO/NF and NiO/NF catalysts. These vibrational peaks are gradually enhanced with increasing catalytic time, indicating the generation of a large number of CNO− intermediates [ 42 ]. Simultaneously, the vibrational peaks of the CNO− intermediates for the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst increased more significantly than those of the NiO/NF catalyst with increasing measurement time, suggesting faster reaction kinetics for the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst. In addition, strong C=O vibrational peaks at ν = 1720 cm−1 were observed in the spectra of NiO/NF catalysts, whereas no obvious accumulation of C=O intermediates was detected for Pt/NiO/NF catalysts [ 43 ]. This is likely due to electron transfer from Pt nanoclusters to the NiO supports in the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts, which enriches the electron density on the NiO surface. Consequently, the lattice oxygen of the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts becomes involved in the reaction, facilitating the conversion of C=O intermediates into COO* intermediates and ultimately into CO2 gas [ 44 ]. The vibrational peak located at ν = 1635 cm−1 in the NiO/NF catalyst spectrum, compared to Pt/NiO/NF (Figs. S41(a), (b)), corresponds to the N–H vibration in amide (– CONNH) groups [ 45 ]. This indicates that the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst possesses a faster kinetic rate for CNO− generation and desorption of adsorbed *COO, enhancing its catalytic performance. In addition, the magnified in situ FTIR spectra (Fig. 6(d)) show diminishing intensities of H2O and C=O peaks in the Pt/NiO/NF spectra over time, attributed to the fast kinetics of the catalyst. This behavior reflects the strong EMSIs between the sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters and the NiO supports, which involve lattice oxygen in the reaction, accelerating the transfer of electrons and promoting desorption of gases from the catalyst surface. To identify the true active center of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst, the structural transformation and the variation in the surface species during the UOR were monitored by in situ Raman spectroscopy. Figs. 6(b) and 6(e) show the in situ Raman spectra of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst, documented from the open-circuit potential to 1.424 V (vs. RHE). At 1.424 V, two intense Raman bands appear at about 475.6 (δ–Ni–O) and 554.4 cm−1 (ν–Ni–O), corresponding to Ni3+–O bending and stretching vibrations of the NiOOH [ 46 ]. These bands signify the evolution of NiO species into NiOOH in both Pt/NiO/NF and NiO/NF catalysts, consistent with XPS results after the UOR stability tests. Compared to NiO/NF, the vibrational peaks of Ni3+–O in Pt/NiO/NF showed a red shift and increased full width at half maximum (FWHM) (Fig. S42), which can be attributed to enhanced material conductivity due to spontaneous rearrangement of electrons at the heterointerface induced by the metal-support interactions in the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst. Additionally, although Pt itself is not catalytically active for UOR, its introduction promotes the electrooxidation of NiO to NiOOH, facilitating the UOR [ 47 ]. DFT calculations (Fig. 6(c)) reveal that Pt/NiO/NF exhibits a higher density of states (DOS) than NiO/NF, indicating electron transfer from Pt to NiO through EMSIs after loading the sub-1 nm Pt nanocluster on the NiO support, enhancing electronic conductivity in Pt/NiO/NF. These results indicate that the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts follow the UOR reaction pathway, as depicted in Fig. 6(f). Initially, Pt/NiO/NF undergoes a self-oxidation reaction (NSOR) of nickel species to form a highly valent reactive Ni3+ species, which then acts as the reactive species for electrocatalytic urea oxidation. The adsorption energy of urea molecules on the electrocatalyst surface is an essential predictor of the UOR catalytic activity. The calculated structural models and energies of urea adsorption on various active sites of the Pt/NiOOH catalyst are shown in Fig. 6(g). The adsorption energy for urea on the PtNi site at the Pt/NiOOH interface is –1.27 eV, significantly lower than that of the top Pt site (–0.16 eV) and the Ni site (–0.54 eV). This result demonstrates that heterointerface construction between Pt and NiOOH optimizes the free energy of urea adsorption on the PtNi sites at the Pt/NiOOH interface, enhancing reaction kinetics for the rate-limiting step of UOR and thereby improving catalytic activity. To elucidate the detailed mechanism of the UOR catalytic process, DFT calculations were used to determine the adsorption energies of different intermediates on the catalyst surface. The conversion of *urea into *OCN2 was identified as the rate-determining step (RDS) for NiOOH. The optimized model of the Pt/NiOOH catalyst and the adapted model for each intermediate on the catalyst surface are shown in Fig. 6(h). The calculated results (Fig. 6(i)) indicate that the RDS free energy for Pt/NiOOH (1.86 eV) is significantly lower than that for the NiOOH catalyst (5.07 eV), confirming that the heterointerface between Pt and NiOOH is essential for designing efficient UOR catalysts. Based on the above discussion, the excellent HER and UOR performances of the as-prepared Pt/NiO/NF catalysts can be attributed to the following factors: (1) The unique 1D/2D nanotube/nanosheet hierarchical structures of NiO supports enable the confined growth of sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters, ensuring successful fabrication of sub-nanometer-scale Pt clusters and improving Pt atom utilization; (2) SMSI between the sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters and NiO supports regulates electron distribution on the catalyst surface, enhancing durability and resistance to degradation; (3) The abundant heterointerfaces between the sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters and NiO supports facilitate electron transfer from the Pt clusters to the NiO supports, optimizing the adsorption/desorption of reactive intermediates on the Pt/NiO/NF surfaces. 3.6 Catalytic activity toward overall electrolysis Given the excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic activity of the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst for both the HER and UOR, an energy-saving hydrogen generation system was developed by coupling the HER and UOR using Pt/NiO/NF electrodes (Fig. 7(a) ). For comparison, a conventional water electrolysis system coupling the HER and OER was also constructed using the same electrodes. Notably, the effect of battery voltage reduction in the coupled HER||UOR system becomes more significant with increasing current density. At a current density of 50 mA cm−2, the coupled HER||UOR system with Pt/NiO/NF catalysts reduced the cell voltage to 290 mV, substantially lower than that of the conventional water electrolysis system (Fig. 7(b)). Meanwhile, the current density of the HER||UOR system at a cell voltage of 1.53 V (equivalent to a current density of 50 mA cm−2) is approximately 142 times higher than that of the water electrolysis system, highlighting the effectiveness of replacing the OER with the UOR for energy-efficient hydrogen production (Fig. 7(c)). Under the same HER||UOR coupling conditions, the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst outperformed NiO/NF and other precious metal-based catalysts, indicating its superiority for bifunctional electrocatalytic performance (Fig. 7(d)). At a current density of 10 mA cm−2, the cell voltage for Pt/NiO/NF was only 1.37 V, compared to 1.60 V for NiO/NF and 1.50 V for Pt/C RuO. These results underscore the potential of modulating the electronic structure of the Pt sub-nanoclusters and NiO supports through targeted metal-support interactions to significantly enhance electrocatalytic activity and efficiency. Video S1 shows the process of H2 generation in the HER||UOR system using a commercial 1.5 V alkaline manganese battery as the power source. At a cell voltage of 1.5 V, N2 and CO2 bubbles were first generated at the anode through the UOR, followed by the vigorous release of H2 bubbles at the cathode. This indicates that the sub-1 nm Pt nanocluster catalysts loaded on NiO supports with a nanotube/nanosheet hierarchical structure enhance electrolyte-catalyst interactions and provide an efficient diffusion channel for the rapid release of gaseous products. Notably, the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst demonstrated excellent stability, with no performance decay observed after 60 h of continuous hydrogen production in the multi-step chronopotentiometric test (Fig. 7(e)). The Faraday efficiency of the HER was calculated to be 100% (Fig. 7(f)), based on the collected H2 volume generated from the reaction and matching the theoretical value (Fig. S43). These results confirm the outstanding hydrogen generation capability of Pt/NiO/NF catalysts in the HER||UOR system. Compared to other reported Pt-based catalysts, the Pt/NiO/NF catalysts exhibited excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic activity (Table S6). This demonstrates the promise of using metal-support interactions to construct Pt/NiO/NF catalysts with sub-nanometer dimensions as efficient electrodes for high-performance H2 production in HER||UOR systems. 4 Conclusions In summary, we uniformly anchored sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters on NiO supports with 1D/2D nanotube/nanosheet hierarchical structures and constructed SMSIs in the heterostructures through space confinement and annealing. The unique hierarchical structure of the NiO supports facilitated the confined growth of sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters, preventing their migration into larger sizes during formation and reducing detachment during the HER/UOR process. The SMSI formed between the sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters and NiO supports induced spontaneous electron rearrangement at the heterointerface, modulating the adsorption/desorption of the reaction intermediates on the surface of the obtained Pt/NiO/NF catalysts and thereby enhancing their catalytic activity. Notably, in situ characterization and theoretical calculations revealed that the SMSI formed between the sub-1 nm Pt nanocluster and NiO support endows the Pt/NiO/NF catalyst with multiple active sites, which simultaneously promote the HER and UOR for efficient electrochemical reactions. This study indicates that NiO with a nanotube/nanosheet hierarchical structure as a support not only enables fine dispersion and stabilization of Pt nanoclusters but also modulates the electronic properties of Pt atoms, thereby improving their utilization during the catalytic process. coredata.dc:description: To address the high cost and limited electrochemical endurance of Pt-based electrocatalysts, the appropriate introduction of transition metal-based compounds as supports to disperse and anchor Pt species offers a promising approach for improving catalytic efficiency. In this study, sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters were uniformly confined on NiO supports with a hierarchical nanotube/nanosheet structure (Pt/NiO/NF) through a combination of spatial domain confinement and annealing. The resulting catalyst exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity and stability for hydrogen evolution (HER) and urea oxidation reactions (UOR) under alkaline conditions. Structural characterization and density functional theory calculations demonstrated that sub-1 nm Pt nanoclusters were immobilized on the NiO supports by Pt–O–Ni bonds at the interface. The strong metal-support interaction induced massive charge redistribution around the heterointerface, leading to the formation of multiple active sites. The Pt/NiO/NF catalyst only required an overpotential of 12 and 136 mV to actuate current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 for the HER, respectively, and maintained a voltage retention of 96% for 260 h of continuous operation at a current density of 500 mA cm−2. Notably, in energy-efficient hydrogen production systems coupled with the HER and UOR, the catalyst required cell voltages of 1.37 and 1.53 V to drive current densities of 10 and 50 mA cm−2, respectively—approximately 300 mV lower than conventional water electrolysis systems. This study presents a novel pathway for designing highly efficient and robust sub-nanometer metal cluster catalysts.
